procedure.summary: Slice the flesh from 6 or 7 large mangoes.
procedure.description: Rinse the mangoes and put them on a cutting board. Hold a mango against the board and carefully cut down 1 side of it. Try to cut as close to the seed in the center, so you're able to remove the most fruit. Then, slice down the other side of the mango. Scoop the flesh from both pieces and chop it into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces. Use a small knife to trim the flesh around the seed itself. You should get around 4 cups (660 g) of mango pieces.

procedure.summary: Put the mango pieces in a pot with sugar, lemon juice, and pectin.
procedure.description: Place the chopped mango in a large pot on the stove. Add 1 cup (200 g) of sugar, 4 tablespoons (59 ml) of lemon juice, and 2 tablespoons (25 g) of powdered pectin. The pectin helps the jam set up. If you prefer a looser jam, you can leave the pectin out.

procedure.summary: Stir the mixture and cook it over low heat until the sugar dissolves.
procedure.description: Stir well so the mango pieces are coated with the sugar. Continue to stir the mixture every few minutes until the sugar dissolves and becomes liquidy. It should take about 3 to 4 minutes for the sugar to dissolve.

procedure.summary: Bring the jam to a boil over medium-high heat.
procedure.description: Turn the burner up so the liquid becomes syrupy and starts to bubble vigorously. Stir the jam occasionally to prevent it from sticking to the pot or boiling over. It's important to use a large pot so the jam doesn't bubble over as it cooks.

procedure.summary: Cook the mango jam until it reaches 220 °F (104 °C).
procedure.description: Clip a candy thermometer to the side of the pot or occasionally insert an instant-read thermometer into the jam to see if the jam has reached the setting temperature of 220 °F (104 °C). Stir the jam occasionally as it bubbles and thickens.Tip: If you don't have a thermometer, place a small plate in the freezer when you begin to make the jam. To test if the jam has set, spoon a coin-sized amount onto the chilled plate and push your finger into it. The jam should wrinkle and hold its shape. Skim off foam that floats to the top of the jam and discard it since becomes rubbery if you leave it in the jam.

procedure.summary: Spoon the jam into sterilized jars.
procedure.description: Get out 2 sterilized half-pint jars and place a funnel on a jar. Carefully spoon the mango jam into the jar and leave ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) headspace. Place a sterilized lid on the jar and screw on a band until it's finger tight. Although you can soften the lids in hot water before pressing them on the jars, you don't have to in order to get a good seal.

procedure.summary: Process the jars or store them in the refrigerator.
procedure.description: For long-term storage, place the jars in a water bath so they're covered by at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water. Boil the jars for 10 minutes and then set the jars aside until the jars are at room temperature. If you don't want to can the jam, put the jars in the refrigerator and use them within 3 weeks. If you process the jam, store the jars at room temperature for up to 1 year. Press down on the lid to check that the seal doesn't pop back up before you open the jar and eat the jam.
